docs.text: About Me Hi! I am a postdoc at the University of Michigan, where I work with Rada Mihalcea and Lu Wang on computational social science. I am currently investigating societal biases in text and models across languages and cultures. I did my PhD at Johns Hopkins University's Center for Language and Speech Processing , where I worked with David Yarowsky on NLP across thousands of languages, with a focus on low-resource languages. Before that, I received my MSE in computer science from JHU in 2017, and I received a BS in computer science as a Turing Scholar and BA in Latin from UT Austin, where I worked with Katrin Erk on computational semantics. My research largely falls under AI for Social Good. Broadly, I seek to develop language technologies that educate and improve our lives. My current work is helping us understand how societal biases manifest in the language we produce and models trained on that language. Most of my past work is on breaking down language barriers and is related to multilinguality, low-resource machine translation, and historical linguistics. See publications for a list of publications. I also enjoy teaching and have taught in a variety of settings. In addition, I am an avid musician . You can reach me at wuws at umich dot edu.

docs.title: About Me

docs.text: Music I am an avid musician. I was one of the winners of the Hopkins Symphony Orchestra Concerto Competition in 2016. I am the founder and president of the JHU Piano Club, and I also play the erhu and arrange music for the Hopkins Oriental Music Ensemble. I have also won several awards with music-related projects at recent hackathons including PeabodyHacks 2019, PeabodyHacks 2020 , and Hophacks 2020

Teaching I enjoy teaching. I was the instructor for EN 500.111 - Multilingual Natural Language Processing (Fall 2019, Fall 2020), a new HEART course I designed to introduce freshmen to research in multilingual NLP. This class is suitable for students right out of high school, with no background in linguistics, math, or computer science. I have also been the teaching assistant for EN 601.466/666 - Information Retrieval and Web Agents (Spring 2018, Spring 2019 , and Spring 2021 ). I also have experience teaching piano lessons and Latin. At JHU, I helped organize North American Computational Linguistics Olympiad events. This is a yearly national competition for middle school and high school students, with lots of fun and challenging puzzles! We do outreach to local schools and host a competition every year.
docs.title: Teaching
